wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Matrix Vision Systems website. Explain its purpose as a professional business frontend for an IT solutions company in Kenya, showcasing services, projects, team, and lead generation capabilities. Describe the architectural foundation using Next.js 13.4+, React 18, and Bootstrap 5, emphasizing component-based design and static data-driven content. Document the relationship between core components such as layout wrappers, SEO implementation, and dynamic routing. Include practical examples of how the homepage variations (home-2 through home-5) demonstrate flexible UI composition. Address beginner onboarding and advanced customization paths, highlighting key technical decisions like GSAP for animations and react-hook-form for validation. Provide context on deployment strategy and performance optimization features like image optimization and critical CSS inlining.

wiki_catalogs.name: Page Routing Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Next.js file-based routing implementation in the matrix repository. Explain how static routes are defined by file names in the src/pages directory, including the role of _app.jsx for global state and layout and _document.jsx for HTML document structure customization. Detail the purpose of key pages like index.jsx (home), about.jsx, contact.jsx, and the 404 error page. Illustrate how page components are structured as React functional components and integrated into the routing system. Provide examples from the codebase showing page exports and their rendering behavior. Address the relationship between file paths and URL routes, and explain how Next.js handles client-side navigation and server-side rendering for these pages. Include best practices for organizing static pages and maintaining consistent layout through wrapper components.

wiki_catalogs.name: SCSS Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the SCSS modular architecture. Explain the role of each top-level directory: components for reusable UI elements, layout for page-specific styling, and utils for global variables, mixins, and helpers. Detail how main.scss imports all partials in a structured order to ensure proper cascade and specificity. Illustrate how the component-based SCSS structure mirrors the React component organization in src/components. Provide examples from _buttons.scss and _accordion.scss to show BEM-like naming conventions and modifier patterns. Describe the compilation pipeline from SCSS to CSS and integration with Next.js via index.scss.

wiki_catalogs.name: Context API Usage
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the React Context API implementation in the Matrix website. Explain how ContextProvider.js manages global UI state such as mouse enter/leave events to enable hover-reveal animations across components. Document the provider pattern implementation, context initialization with useState, and how value objects are passed to consumers. Illustrate with examples from hero-banner.jsx and wrapper.jsx where context-driven animations respond to user interactions. Detail best practices used in the codebase to prevent unnecessary re-renders, such as memoizing context values and using granular contexts. Address the scalability of this approach and why it suffices for this application without requiring Redux or other external state management libraries. Include troubleshooting tips for common context-related issues like stale closures or missing providers in the component tree.

wiki_catalogs.name: Home Page Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the home page component architecture. Explain how each home variant (home through home-5) is structured as a composite component using specialized sub-components like hero-area, service-area, and testimonial-area. Illustrate the pattern of index.jsx serving as the container that orchestrates layout and data flow from static sources. Highlight differences in design focus between variants (e.g., home-2 emphasizing payment solutions, home-4 focusing on security). Document the use of animation integration via AnimateMouse.js in home-5 and how reusable areas like cta-area and price-area are shared across variants. Provide examples of conditional rendering and prop drilling for dynamic content. Address common issues such as animation conflicts and layout consistency across home versions, with solutions observed in the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: SEO Implementation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on SEO implementation. Thoroughly explain how the SEO component manages meta tags, Open Graph data, Twitter cards, and JSON-LD structured data for rich snippets. Document the implementation of dynamic metadata generation using props across different page types (services, projects, blog posts). Include concrete examples from src/common/seo.jsx showing default values, URL construction, and image handling. Explain the integration pattern where SEO is consumed by all pages via _app.jsx. Detail the technical SEO configurations in next.config.js including security headers, redirects, and image optimization settings. Address common issues like duplicate content prevention with canonical URLs, proper indexing control via robots meta tags, and country-specific geo-targeting for Kenya and East Africa. Provide optimization tips for improving Core Web Vitals and Lighthouse scores through metadata efficiency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Form Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the implementation and structure of form components in the Matrix Vision Systems website. Explain the role of each form component (contact-us-form, register-form, login-form, comment-post, hero-form) within the application, their JSX structure, and how they integrate with the overall UI. Document the use of controlled components, form state management via react-hook-form, and handling of user input. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how fields are registered, how default values are set, and how submission handlers are defined. Describe the composition pattern used to reuse form elements and validation logic. Address accessibility features such as proper labeling, focus management, and ARIA attributes. Illustrate how success and error states are visually communicated to users after submission.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Models Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the core content entities in the Matrix Vision Systems website. Detail the structure of key data files including service-data.js, blog-data.js, project-data.js, team-data.js, and testimonial-data.js. Explain that each file exports an array of objects with standardized properties such as id, title, description, and image. Document the consistent naming conventions and type patterns used across all data models. Illustrate how these static JavaScript objects serve as the content layer for the entire application, eliminating the need for a backend CMS. Provide examples of how these data structures map directly to UI components like ServiceArea, ProjectArea, and TestimonialArea. Address the benefits of this approach for performance in Next.js, including build-time rendering and reduced client-side fetching. Include guidance on extending these models with new fields while maintaining consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: GSAP Integration with React
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for GSAP integration within the React component lifecycle. Explain how GSAP timelines are created and managed inside custom React hooks to prevent memory leaks and ensure proper cleanup. Document the use of useIsomorphicEffect to handle server-side rendering compatibility. Illustrate how animation configurations are abstracted into reusable hooks like useTitleAnimation and useCharAnimation, enabling consistent text animation patterns across pages. Provide code examples from hero-banner.jsx showing sequential and staggered animations. Address best practices for avoiding re-renders by memoizing animation logic and managing dependencies in useEffect. Include performance considerations such as reducing DOM queries and leveraging GSAP's internal optimizations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Breakpoints and Media Queries
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the responsive breakpoints system used in the Matrix Vision Systems website. Explain the mobile-first breakpoint configuration defined in _breakpoints.scss, including the specific pixel thresholds for mobile, tablet, and desktop screens. Document how custom SCSS mixins in _mixins.scss enable clean media query usage across components. Illustrate how these breakpoints integrate with Bootstrap 5's grid system to create fluid layouts. Provide real code examples from header and footer components showing responsive layout shifts. Address the rationale behind chosen breakpoint values and their alignment with target device resolutions. Include guidance on extending or modifying breakpoints for new device support and warn about potential conflicts with Bootstrap's native breakpoints.

wiki_catalogs.name: SCSS Utilities System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the SCSS utilities system. Explain the purpose and implementation of global design tokens including color palettes, typography scales, and responsive breakpoints. Detail how _root.scss establishes CSS custom properties for theme consistency. Describe the functionality of key mixins in _mixins.scss such as responsive breakpoints, hover transitions, and animation helpers. Illustrate how _colors.scss and _typography.scss serve as single sources of truth for design system values. Provide examples of how these utilities are consumed across components and layout styles. Document the role of _index.scss in barrel-exporting utilities for simplified imports. Address best practices for extending the utility system while maintaining design consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the Matrix website. Detail the core frameworks: Next.js 13.4+ for SSR and routing, React 18 for component architecture, and Bootstrap 5 for responsive layout. Explain the role of GSAP and ScrollTrigger for advanced animations, react-slick and Swiper.js for carousels, and react-countup for animated counters. Document form handling with react-hook-form and Yup validation, state management via Context API, and UI enhancements with react-modal-video and NiceSelect. Cover build and optimization tools including Sass for CSS preprocessing and Critters for critical CSS inlining. Include version compatibility notes, dependency interrelationships, and rationale behind key technology choices. Provide examples of how these libraries integrate, such as GSAP hooks working with React components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dynamic Routing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the dynamic routing implementation in the matrix application. Explain how Next.js dynamic routes work using bracket syntax ([project].jsx and [service].jsx) to create parameterized pages for project and service details. Describe how getStaticPaths and getStaticProps (or equivalent data-fetching methods) are used to generate static pages at build time based on data from project-data.js and service-data.js. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how route parameters are extracted and used to fetch corresponding data entries. Document the URL patterns for dynamic routes (e.g., /project-details/project-name) and how they map to service and project slugs. Explain the benefits of static site generation for SEO and performance. Address common issues such as handling invalid slugs, fallback behavior, and ensuring data consistency between route parameters and data files. Include guidance on adding new dynamic entries and maintaining the data-to-route mapping.

wiki_catalogs.name: Utility Styling System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the utility-first styling approach used in the codebase. Explain how _spacing.scss and spacing.css provide margin/padding utilities for rapid layout creation. Detail the typography scale defined in _typography.scss, including font sizes, weights, and line heights. Describe the color system in _colors.scss that enables consistent theming across components. Show how these utilities are consumed in React components like hero-banner.jsx and service-area.jsx. Include practical examples of combining utility classes for responsive layouts. Address performance benefits of utility-first CSS and how animate.css integrates for micro-interactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Custom Hooks
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the custom React hooks used throughout the Matrix website. Detail each hook's purpose: useSticky for scroll-based header behavior, useIsomorphicEffect for safe SSR hydration, useTitleAnimation and useCharAnimation for GSAP-powered text animations, and useMultipleAnime for complex sequence animations. Explain how these hooks encapsulate stateful logic and side effects while maintaining reusability across components. Provide code examples showing hook usage in components like hero-banner.jsx and breadcrumb components. Document the internal implementation of useIsomorphicEffect to handle window object access during SSR. Include performance considerations such as cleanup functions in useEffect, dependency array optimization, and avoiding memory leaks in animation hooks. Address common issues like animation glitches during hydration and provide solutions implemented in the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the service component architecture. Describe how the service/index.jsx acts as a container for service listings using service-area.jsx to render individual service cards. Explain the data-driven design where service data from src/data/service-data.js is passed via props. Detail the structure of service-details components, including dynamic routing via [service].jsx and specialized pages like Customer-Relations-Management.jsx. Illustrate how service-details-area.jsx provides a consistent layout for detailed service descriptions. Document the composition pattern where complex service pages are built from reusable elements. Provide examples of prop usage, conditional rendering for different service types, and integration with SEO components. Address common issues like content overflow and inconsistent styling, with solutions from the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Accessibility Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on accessibility features. Thoroughly explain the implementation of WCAG 2.1 AA compliance throughout the codebase, starting with semantic HTML structure in layout components. Document the use of ARIA labels and roles in interactive elements like navigation menus, modals, and form controls. Describe keyboard navigation support across all UI components including dropdowns, carousels, and modals. Illustrate how the SEO component contributes to accessibility through proper page titles and meta descriptions. Provide examples from the codebase such as accessible form controls in contact forms, focus management in the mobile menu, and screen reader support in UI components like NiceSelect. Address common accessibility issues and their solutions, including color contrast ratios, text resizing, and motion preferences. Include testing methodologies using tools like axe, Lighthouse, and screen readers to validate compliance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Validation Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the validation strategy used across forms in the application. Thoroughly explain the integration between react-hook-form and Yup for schema-based validation, including resolver configuration and error handling. Detail the custom validation utilities provided in formUtils.js, such as email, phone, and required field validators, and how they are reused across different forms. Document the structure of validation schemas, including field rules, error messages, and conditional validation logic. Provide code examples from contact-us-form and register-form showing how validation is implemented. Explain how validation errors are displayed in the UI and synchronized with form state. Address best practices followed in the codebase for performance (e.g., onBlur triggering) and user experience. Include guidance on extending validation rules for new forms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Data Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the service data architecture. Explain how service-data.js defines the main service catalog with core properties (id, title, short_description, icon, image) used in service listings. Describe how service-details-data.js contains richer content (detailed_description, features, benefits, case_studies) for individual service detail pages. Document the relationship between these data files and dynamic routing in Next.js via [service].jsx pages. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how the slug property in service-data.js maps to URL routes. Explain the component consumption pattern where ServiceArea maps service-data.js entries to UI cards, while [service].jsx pages use the slug to fetch corresponding details from service-details-data.js. Address content update workflows for adding new services and ensuring data consistency between the two files.

wiki_catalogs.name: Scroll-Triggered Animations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for scroll-based animations powered by GSAP ScrollTrigger. Detail how ScrollTrigger instances are initialized in wrapper.jsx to control entrance animations for sections like features, testimonials, and counters. Explain the implementation of sticky headers using use-sticky.js and how they interact with scroll position. Describe the CSS classes and SCSS utilities in _animation.scss that define animation states (e.g., animate__fadeInUp). Provide examples of trigger elements and offset configurations used to synchronize animations with viewport visibility. Include guidance on setting duration, easing, and scrub behavior. Address common issues such as flickering animations, incorrect trigger points, and solutions for mobile responsiveness. Recommend performance optimization techniques like scroller proxy and lazy-creating triggers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Responsive Navigation Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for responsive navigation implementation across the application. Explain the dual navigation pattern: desktop dropdown menus in header.jsx versus mobile offcanvas menus powered by MeanMenu CSS and mobile-menus.jsx. Detail how the offcanvus component enables touch-friendly menu interactions on small screens. Describe the state management and event handling that toggles mobile menus. Provide examples of how navigation adapts content density and interaction models based on screen size. Document accessibility considerations for keyboard navigation and screen readers in both desktop and mobile modes. Include performance tips for minimizing re-renders during menu interactions and troubleshooting common issues like menu overlap or touch delay.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Styles Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SCSS component styles architecture. Explain how each component partial corresponds to React components in src/components and follows a BEM-like naming convention for specificity control. Detail the structure of _buttons.scss including base styles, size variants, and state modifiers. Illustrate how _accordion.scss implements expandable content panels with smooth transitions. Describe the styling approach for interactive components like modals, tabs, and offcanvas menus. Show how _theme.scss applies visual treatments that align with the brand identity. Provide code examples demonstrating how component styles are scoped and avoid global leakage. Address how these styles integrate with React's className prop system and support dynamic styling through utility classes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on setting up the Matrix website development environment. Provide step-by-step instructions for installing Node.js, cloning the repository, and running npm install to resolve dependencies. Document how to start the development server using 'npm run dev', build for production with 'npm run build', and run in production mode with 'npm start'. Explain environment-specific configurations in next.config.js, including image optimization settings and security headers. Include troubleshooting tips for common setup issues like port conflicts or missing dependencies. Demonstrate basic project structure navigation and how to verify the installation through browser access. Address prerequisites such as required Node.js version and npm/yarn knowledge.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation Menus
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the navigation menu system in the matrix website. Detail how menu-data.js defines the navigation structure as a JavaScript object with hierarchical items, URLs, and metadata that drives multiple header variants. Explain how the NavMenu component consumes this data to render desktop navigation with dropdowns and responsive behavior. Describe the integration with mobile-menus.jsx for the meanmenu implementation on smaller screens. Illustrate how active link states are managed using Next.js router hooks to highlight current pages. Document the relationship between menu items and actual page routes, including special cases like external links or dropdown sections. Provide examples from the codebase showing menu configuration and component rendering logic. Address accessibility considerations such as keyboard navigation and ARIA attributes. Include customization guidelines for modifying menu structure and adding new navigation items while maintaining consistency across header variants.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Styling Patterns
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for component-level SCSS styling patterns. Focus on how each component SCSS file (e.g., _buttons.scss) defines styles for corresponding React components using consistent naming conventions. Explain modifier classes for variations (e.g., btn-primary, btn-lg). Use _accordion.scss to demonstrate nested styling and state-based rules (:hover, :focus). Illustrate how _modal.scss handles z-index stacking and transitions. Show integration points with React via className bindings in components like modal.jsx. Include best practices for scoping styles to prevent leakage and ensure reusability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Project Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the project component architecture. Explain how project/index.jsx serves as the main container for project listings, utilizing portfolio.jsx for grid-based display of projects using data from src/data/project-data.js. Detail the structure of project details pages, including dynamic routing via [project].jsx and the role of project-details-area.jsx in presenting comprehensive project information. Describe the thumb-area.jsx component for thumbnail navigation and its integration with image galleries. Illustrate the composition pattern where project pages combine multiple sub-components for a cohesive presentation. Provide examples of data flow from static files to UI components, prop usage for image handling, and responsive design considerations. Address common issues like image loading performance and gallery navigation, with optimization techniques used in the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Form Handling & Backend Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the form submission endpoint handled by mail.php. Document the HTTP POST interface that receives form data from frontend React components, including expected request payload structure (name, email, message, etc.) and content-type handling. Explain the server-side validation and sanitization logic in mail.php to prevent email injection and ensure data integrity. Detail the email delivery mechanism using PHP's mail() function, including headers, recipient configuration, and message formatting. Describe the security considerations implemented, such as input escaping and CSRF mitigation through frontend validation. Outline the success/error response flow back to the frontend and how user feedback is rendered. Include client implementation guidelines from the React forms showing how fetch requests are structured, and provide troubleshooting tips for common issues like failed submissions or spam filtering.

wiki_catalogs.name: Project Data Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the project data structure. Detail how project-data.js contains a curated list of projects with metadata (id, title, category, image, tags) used for the project showcase grid. Explain how project-details-data.js holds in-depth information (full_description, challenges, solutions, technologies, results) for specific project case studies. Document the implementation of dynamic routing where [project].jsx pages use the project slug to retrieve corresponding details. Provide examples from the codebase showing how Portfolio component maps project-data.js entries to project cards with category filtering. Address the data relationship between the summary and detailed views, and explain how images and technology stacks are structured for consistent presentation. Include best practices for maintaining project case studies and updating technical specifications.

wiki_catalogs.name: Hover & Reveal Effects
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for interactive hover and reveal effects managed through React Context and CSS. Explain how ContextProvider tracks mouse enter/leave events and propagates animation states to child components. Document the integration between hover-reveal.css and React components to enable smooth reveal animations on cards, buttons, and navigation items. Illustrate how dynamic classes are applied based on context state to trigger CSS transitions. Provide real examples from hero-banner.jsx where hover effects enhance call-to-action visibility. Address accessibility concerns by ensuring keyboard navigability and ARIA labeling. Include fallback styles for touch devices and performance tips for minimizing repaints during hover interactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Layout Component Adaptation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for how layout components adapt across screen sizes, focusing on headers and footers. Explain the structural changes in header.jsx, such as logo placement, navigation compression, and CTA button visibility toggling. Describe footer.jsx's responsive column stacking and content reorganization on mobile. Illustrate with examples from home-5/hero-area.jsx how hero sections maintain visual impact while adjusting typography, spacing, and call-to-action positioning on smaller screens. Document the use of Bootstrap utility classes and custom SCSS for responsive spacing and alignment. Address challenges in maintaining brand consistency while optimizing for usability across devices and provide solutions for common layout breakage issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Layout Styles System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SCSS layout styles system. Explain how layout partials correspond to page sections and templates in src/pages and src/components/homes. Detail the styling approach for major page sections including hero, service, project, and blog layouts. Describe the implementation of responsive grid systems and flexbox layouts for content organization. Illustrate how _header.scss and _footer.scss handle complex navigation and multi-column layouts. Show how page-specific styles in _about.scss, _contact.scss, and _career.scss maintain visual consistency while accommodating unique content structures. Provide examples of how layout styles interact with component styles and utility classes. Address the mobile-first approach and breakpoint management across different layout types.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the React component architecture of the Matrix website. Explain the component hierarchy starting from _app.jsx and wrapper.jsx that provide global layout and context. Detail the organization of components into feature-based directories (homes, service, project, etc.) and reusable common components. Describe the composition pattern where complex pages are built from smaller, single-responsibility components like hero-area.jsx and service-area.jsx. Illustrate how props are used to pass data from pages to components, particularly from static data files. Provide examples of component reuse across different home variants and how conditional rendering enables UI flexibility. Address best practices in component design observed in the codebase, such as separation of presentational and container components.

wiki_catalogs.name: Layout-Specific Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for layout-level styling implementation. Explain how each layout SCSS file corresponds to major page sections or templates (e.g., _service.scss for service pages). Use _header.scss to illustrate responsive navigation styling with mobile breakpoints. Show how _hero.scss implements full-screen banners with layered elements and animations. Describe the grid and flexbox patterns used in _project.scss for portfolio layouts. Demonstrate how these styles are applied in React components like home-2.jsx and service-area.jsx. Address challenges in maintaining consistency across multiple layout variants while allowing customization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Blog Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the blog component architecture. Describe how blog/index.jsx orchestrates the blog listing using blog-grid.jsx and portfolio.jsx for layout. Explain the data flow from src/data/blog-data.js to blog components and the role of portfolio.jsx in rendering blog cards. Detail the blog-details components, including banner.jsx for featured images, comments.jsx for user engagement, and postbox-area.jsx for comment submission. Illustrate the blog-list components that provide sidebar functionality like categories, recent posts, and tags. Document the composition pattern where blog pages integrate multiple interactive elements. Provide examples of prop usage for dynamic content, form integration in postbox-area, and responsive design for blog layouts. Address common issues like comment form validation and category filtering, with solutions implemented in the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Blog Content Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the blog content management system. Explain how blog-data.js serves as the central repository for all blog posts with properties like id, title, excerpt, content, author, publish_date, category, and featured_image. Document the structure of categories and tags for content organization. Illustrate how blog posts are consumed by different components: blog-grid.jsx for homepage showcases, blog-list.jsx for category archives, and blog-details.jsx for full article views. Provide examples of data transformation, such as date formatting and content truncation for excerpts. Address the workflow for adding new blog posts, including proper image optimization and SEO metadata considerations. Explain how related posts are generated based on category and tag matching within the static data structure.

wiki_catalogs.name: Text & Character Animations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for character-level text animations using GSAP and custom hooks. Explain how useCharAnimation splits text into individual characters and applies staggered animations for typewriter or fade-in effects. Describe the implementation of animated breadcrumb titles via useBreadcrumbTitleAnime.js and its integration with page transitions. Provide usage examples from hero-banner.jsx showing animated headlines with delay sequences. Document configuration options such as delay, duration, easing, and split type (words, chars, lines). Address challenges like text reflow during animation, font loading impact, and synchronization with layout shifts. Include strategies for graceful degradation when JavaScript is disabled or animations are reduced.

wiki_catalogs.name: Responsive Utilities and Helper Classes
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for responsive utility classes used throughout the codebase. Explain the purpose and implementation of spacing utilities in _spacing.scss and spacing.css that enable responsive margin and padding adjustments. Document how mixins in _mixins.scss generate responsive variants of utility classes. Illustrate practical usage examples where components use these utilities to adapt spacing, visibility, and alignment across breakpoints. Show how developers can leverage these helpers to quickly implement responsive designs without writing custom CSS. Address best practices for avoiding utility class bloat and maintaining code readability. Include guidance on creating new responsive utilities when needed and integrating them with the existing SCSS architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Routing & Navigation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Next.js routing system and navigation implementation. Explain how the file-based routing works with the src/pages directory, including static routes (about.jsx) and dynamic routes ([project].jsx, [service].jsx). Detail the structure of menu-data.js that drives the navigation links across header variants. Describe how the NavMenu component renders responsive navigation with desktop and mobile (meanmenu) implementations. Illustrate the integration between routing and layout components, showing how headers and footers persist across page transitions. Provide examples of link creation using Next.js Link component and how active states are managed. Address SEO implications of the routing structure and client-side navigation benefits.

wiki_catalogs.name: Theme and Variables System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the theming system based on CSS variables and SCSS preprocessing. Detail how _root.scss defines CSS custom properties for dynamic theming. Explain the role of _colors.scss in maintaining brand consistency through semantic color names. Show how _typography.scss standardizes text styles across the application. Illustrate how _theme.scss enables theme switching via class toggling. Provide examples of consuming these variables in component styles and JavaScript (via getComputedStyle). Discuss advantages of combining SCSS variables with CSS custom properties for both build-time and runtime theming.

wiki_catalogs.name: Team Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the team component architecture. Explain how team/index.jsx serves as the main container for team member listings using team-area.jsx to render individual profiles with data from src/data/team-data.js. Detail the team-details components, including dynamic routing and the role of team-details-area.jsx in presenting comprehensive member information. Describe the individual team member components (e.g., eric-atinga.jsx) that provide specialized content for key personnel. Illustrate the composition pattern where team pages integrate biographical information, expertise, and contact details. Provide examples of prop usage for image and social link handling, responsive design for team grids, and accessibility considerations. Address common issues like inconsistent profile formatting and image optimization, with standardization approaches used in the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Team Data Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the team data model. Detail how team-data.js structures team member information with properties including id, name, role, bio, experience, skills, social_links, and profile_image. Explain how this data powers both the team grid view (team-area.jsx) and individual detail pages. Document the relationship between static team data and dynamic page generation for team members. Provide examples from the codebase showing how social links are rendered as icons and skills are displayed as progress bars. Address the content update process for team changes, including onboarding new members and updating role descriptions. Include guidance on maintaining consistent bio formatting and image requirements for professional presentation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Performance & Accessibility
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive content on animation performance optimization and accessibility compliance. Explain how useIsomorphicEffect prevents hydration mismatches during SSR. Document the use of prefers-reduced-motion media query to disable or simplify animations for users with motion sensitivity, implemented via CSS classes in _animation.scss and conditional logic in hooks. Cover performance techniques such as lazy initialization of animations, throttling scroll handlers, and minimizing forced reflows. Discuss image and script loading impacts on animation smoothness, referencing Next.js image optimization in next.config.js. Include debugging strategies using GSAP's dev tools, Lighthouse audits, and browser performance tabs. Provide guidelines for maintaining 60fps animations and ensuring WCAG 2.1 AA compliance for motion-related interactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Styling Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the SCSS-based styling architecture. Explain the modular SCSS structure with components, layout, and utils directories, and how they compile into main.scss. Detail the utility-first approach with spacing.css and typography variables in _typography.scss. Describe the theme system in _theme.scss and how color variables in _colors.scss enable consistent branding. Explain the use of mixins in _mixins.scss for responsive design and animations. Illustrate how component-specific SCSS files in public/assets/scss/layout correspond to React components. Address the compilation process from SCSS to CSS and how styles are imported in index.scss. Provide examples of class naming conventions and BEM-like patterns used in the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Mixins and Responsive Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for responsive design implementation using SCSS mixins. Explain the breakpoint system defined in _breakpoints.scss and how it aligns with Bootstrap's grid tiers. Demonstrate usage of media query mixins from _mixins.scss for mobile-first development. Use _meanmenu.scss to show how complex mobile navigation is styled responsively. Illustrate how _header.scss applies different layouts at various breakpoints. Provide code examples of mixin usage in component styles and best practices for writing maintainable responsive rules. Address performance considerations and browser compatibility for media queries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contact and Career Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the contact and career component architecture. Describe how contact/index.jsx integrates contact-form-area.jsx for lead generation, office-location.jsx for address display, and cta-area.jsx for call-to-action elements. Explain the form handling process, including integration with mail.php and validation via react-hook-form. Detail the career components, including career/index.jsx for job listings and career-details components for position descriptions. Illustrate the data flow from static sources to UI components and the use of conditional rendering for different contact scenarios. Provide examples of prop usage for form configuration, responsive design for contact layouts, and accessibility features in forms. Address common issues like form submission errors and spam protection, with mitigation strategies implemented in the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dynamic Routing Data Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the dynamic routing data flow pattern. Describe how Next.js dynamic routes ([project].jsx, [service].jsx) retrieve data from static JavaScript files using slug parameters. Explain the implementation of getStaticPaths and getStaticProps (or equivalent App Router patterns) that generate pages at build time from the data arrays. Document the data lookup mechanism using helper functions from utils.js to find items by slug. Illustrate the complete flow from URL request → slug extraction → data lookup → component rendering. Provide concrete examples from project and service detail pages showing how the same pattern is reused across different content types. Address performance benefits of this static generation approach and limitations regarding content updates requiring rebuilds. Include best practices for slug generation and handling edge cases like missing or duplicate slugs.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the state management patterns in the Matrix website. Explain the use of React Context API through ContextProvider.js to manage global UI state like mouse enter/leave events for hover effects. Detail how custom hooks in src/hooks (useSticky, useTitleAnimation, etc.) encapsulate reusable stateful logic and side effects. Describe the isomorphic effect pattern in useIsomorphicEffect.js for safe SSR hydration. Illustrate how animation states are managed through GSAP integration with React hooks. Provide examples of context consumption in components like hero-banner.jsx. Address the limitations of this approach for large-scale state and why Redux was not implemented. Include best practices for avoiding unnecessary re-renders.

wiki_catalogs.name: Common and Layout Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for common and layout components. Explain how src/common contains reusable UI elements like breadcrumbs (multiple variants for different designs), hero-banner.jsx for promotional content, and preloader.jsx for loading states. Describe the layout components, including multiple header and footer variants that provide design flexibility across pages. Detail the wrapper.jsx component that establishes the global application structure and initializes animations. Illustrate how nav-menu.jsx uses menu-data.js to generate navigation dynamically. Document the composition pattern where pages combine header, footer, and wrapper for consistent site-wide layout. Provide examples of prop usage for theme switching, responsive behavior, and accessibility features. Address common issues like mobile menu conflicts and footer positioning, with solutions from the codebase.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the static data architecture. Explain how all content is managed through JavaScript data files in src/data (service-data.js, blog-data.js, etc.) rather than a CMS or database. Describe the structure of these data files as arrays of objects with consistent properties (id, title, description, image, etc.). Illustrate how components consume this data through props passed from pages. Detail the separation between data models and presentation components, enabling easy content updates without touching UI code. Provide examples of data transformation, such as how project-details-data.js maps to dynamic [project].jsx routes. Address content update workflows and localization considerations. Include performance benefits of static data in a Next.js application.

wiki_catalogs.name: SEO & Accessibility
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on SEO and accessibility implementation. Detail the comprehensive SEO component that manages meta tags, Open Graph data, Twitter cards, and structured JSON-LD for rich snippets. Explain how dynamic metadata is generated for different pages using props. Describe accessibility features including semantic HTML, ARIA labels, keyboard navigation support, and WCAG 2.1 AA compliance. Cover technical SEO aspects from next.config.js like security headers, redirects, and image optimization. Illustrate how the SEO component integrates with all pages through _app.jsx. Provide examples of schema markup for services and team members. Address performance metrics impact on SEO and accessibility testing methodologies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Forms & Validation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on form implementation and validation. Explain the use of react-hook-form for efficient form state management and Yup for schema-based validation. Detail the structure of form components (contact-us-form.jsx, register-form.jsx) and their integration with backend processing via mail.php. Describe the utility functions in formUtils.js that handle common validation patterns and error messages. Illustrate the form submission workflow from user input to server processing. Provide examples of validation rules for different form types and how error states are displayed. Address security considerations like CSRF protection and email injection prevention in mail.php. Include accessibility features of form controls and success/error feedback mechanisms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Animations & Interactions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the animation system powered by GSAP. Explain how GSAP is integrated with React through custom hooks like useTitleAnimation and useCharAnimation. Detail the implementation of scroll-triggered animations using ScrollTrigger and how they're initialized in wrapper.jsx. Describe the hover-reveal effects managed through ContextProvider and CSS classes. Illustrate character-by-character text animations and staggered element reveals. Provide examples of animation sequences in hero-banner.jsx and how they enhance user engagement. Address performance optimization techniques like lazy loading animations and reducing re-renders. Include fallback strategies for users with reduced motion preferences.

wiki_catalogs.name: Responsive Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the responsive design implementation. Explain the mobile-first approach using Bootstrap 5 grid system and custom SCSS breakpoints defined in _breakpoints.scss. Detail the responsive navigation patterns with desktop menus and mobile offcanvas menus powered by meanmenu. Describe how layout components adapt across screen sizes, particularly headers and footers. Illustrate the use of utility classes for responsive spacing and visibility. Provide examples of component-level responsiveness in hero sections and service grids. Address touch-friendly interactions and viewport scaling. Include testing methodologies across device sizes and how the design maintains usability on small screens while providing rich experiences on desktop.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on deploying the Matrix website. Explain the production build process using 'next build' and static export capabilities. Detail configuration in next.config.js for output settings, image optimization, and security headers. Describe deployment options including Vercel (default for Next.js), Netlify, and traditional hosting. Cover environment-specific configurations and how to set up custom domains and SSL. Provide guidance on performance optimization post-deployment, including caching strategies and CDN integration. Address monitoring and error tracking setup. Include rollback procedures and version management best practices for production updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contribution Guidelines
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on contributing to the Matrix website codebase. Document the development workflow including branching strategy, commit message conventions, and pull request requirements. Explain coding standards for JavaScript, JSX, and SCSS, including file naming, indentation, and comment practices. Detail the process for adding new pages, components, or data entries. Provide guidelines for maintaining consistency in UI components and animations. Describe testing procedures and how to verify changes locally. Address documentation update requirements for new features. Include information on code review processes and deployment coordination for contributors.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Matrix Vision Systems Website

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
Matrix Vision Systems is a professional IT solutions and digital transformation company based in Kenya, specializing in delivering cutting-edge technology services for enterprise clients. The website serves as a comprehensive digital platform to showcase their expertise in software development, security systems, infrastructure solutions, and managed services.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Present a modern, professional brand image for Matrix Vision Systems
- Effectively communicate the company's wide range of technology solutions and services
- Generate leads through strategic call-to-action elements and contact forms
- Provide an engaging user experience with advanced animations and interactive components
- Optimize for search engines and performance across devices

### Target Audience
- Enterprise decision-makers and IT managers seeking technology solutions
- Organizations requiring digital transformation services
- Businesses in need of security, infrastructure, or software solutions
- Potential clients in Kenya and surrounding regions looking for local technology partners

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The project follows a component-based architecture built on Next.js, with a clear separation of concerns between layout, components, pages, and data. The application is structured around reusable UI components organized by functionality and purpose.

### Design Patterns
The application implements several modern frontend patterns:
- Component composition pattern for building complex UIs from smaller components
- Context API pattern for global state management
- Custom hooks pattern for reusable logic
- Data-driven design pattern where components are populated from data files
- Layout wrapper pattern for consistent application structure

### System Relationships and Data Flow
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client] --> B[Next.js App]
    B --> C[Layout Components]
    C --> D[Header & Navigation]
    C --> E[Main Content]
    C --> F[Footer]
    B --> G[Context Provider]
    G --> H[Global State]
    B --> I[Data Files]
    I --> J[Service Data]
    I --> K[Blog Data]
    I --> L[Team Data]
    D --> M[Menu Data]
    E --> N[Page Components]
    N --> O[Feature Areas]
    O --> P[Reusable Components]
    P --> Q[SVG Icons]
    P --> R[Forms]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `src/pages/_app.jsx` - Application root component that initializes global styles and providers
- `src/pages/index.jsx` - Home page entry point that composes the main layout
- `src/layout/wrapper.jsx` - Global wrapper component that provides consistent structure

### Core Modules
- `src/components/homes/home/index.jsx` - Primary home page component that orchestrates all home sections
- `src/layout/headers/header.jsx` - Navigation header with responsive design and interactive elements
- `src/layout/footers/footer.jsx` - Comprehensive footer with multiple content sections
- `src/context/ContextProvider.js` - Global state management for application-wide variables

### Configuration Approach
- `next.config.js` - Next.js configuration with image optimization, security headers, and performance settings
- `package.json` - Project dependencies and scripts management
- `jsconfig.json` - JavaScript configuration for the project

### External Dependencies
- `next`, `react`, `react-dom` - Core framework dependencies
- `bootstrap` - CSS framework for responsive design
- `gsap` - Animation library for advanced transitions and effects
- `react-slick`, `swiper` - Carousel and slider components
- `react-countup` - Animated number counting
- `react-modal-video` - Video modal functionality
- `sass` - CSS preprocessor for styling

### Integration Points
- Google Maps integration in the footer for location display
- Form handling capabilities for contact and registration
- Social media links and sharing functionality
- Phone and email links for direct communication

### Component Relationship Diagram
```mermaid
graph LR
    App[src/pages/_app.jsx] --> Wrapper[src/layout/wrapper.jsx]
    Wrapper --> Header[src/layout/headers/header.jsx]
    Wrapper --> Footer[src/layout/footers/footer.jsx]
    Wrapper --> Home[src/pages/index.jsx]
    Home --> SEO[src/common/seo]
    Home --> HomeOne[src/components/homes/home/index.jsx]
    HomeOne --> HeroSlider[src/components/homes/home/hero-slider.jsx]
    HomeOne --> FeatureArea[src/components/homes/home/feature-area.jsx]
    HomeOne --> AboutArea[src/common/about-area.jsx]
    HomeOne --> ServicesArea[src/components/homes/home/services-area.jsx]
    HomeOne --> ProjectArea[src/components/homes/home/project-area.jsx]
    HomeOne --> TestimonialArea[src/common/testimonial-area.jsx]
    HomeOne --> RankArea[src/components/homes/home/rank-area.jsx]
    ContextProvider[src/context/ContextProvider.js] --> App
    service_data[src/data/service-data.js] --> ServicesArea
    menu_data[src/layout/headers/menu-data.js] --> Header
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The website features a comprehensive set of capabilities designed to showcase Matrix Vision Systems' offerings, including multiple service categories, project showcases, team information, and contact functionality. The site emphasizes visual appeal with animations and interactive elements while maintaining strong SEO and performance characteristics.

### Implementation Highlights
- Responsive design that adapts to various screen sizes
- Advanced animations using GSAP for engaging user experience
- Multiple home page variations for different use cases
- Comprehensive service catalog with detailed descriptions
- Interactive forms for lead generation
- Team member profiles with individual pages
- Blog functionality for content marketing

### Feature Architecture Diagram
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> HomePage
    HomePage --> ServicePage: Click Services
    HomePage --> ProjectPage: Click Projects
    HomePage --> BlogPage: Click Blog
    HomePage --> AboutPage: Click About Us
    HomePage --> ContactPage: Click Contact
    
    ServicePage --> ServiceDetailPage: Click Specific Service
    ServiceDetailPage --> ContactPage: Click Get Started
    
    ProjectPage --> ProjectDetailPage: Click Project
    ProjectDetailPage --> ContactPage: Click Learn More
    
    AboutPage --> TeamPage: Click Team
    TeamPage --> TeamDetailPage: Click Team Member
    
    ContactPage --> FormSubmitted: Submit Form
    FormSubmitted --> ThankYouPage: Redirect
    
    state HomePage {
        [*] --> HeroSection
        HeroSection --> ServicesSection
        ServicesSection --> AboutSection
        AboutSection --> ProjectsSection
        ProjectsSection --> TestimonialsSection
        TestimonialsSection --> Footer
    }
```

Sources:
- [package.json](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\package.json)
- [next.config.js](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\next.config.js)
- [_app.jsx](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\pages\_app.jsx)
- [index.jsx](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\pages\index.jsx)
- [wrapper.jsx](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\layout\wrapper.jsx)
- [header.jsx](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\layout\headers\header.jsx)
- [footer.jsx](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\layout\footers\footer.jsx)
- [ContextProvider.js](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\context\ContextProvider.js)
- [service-data.js](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\data\service-data.js)
- [menu-data.js](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\layout\headers\menu-data.js)
- [hero-slider.jsx](c:\Matrix-website\matrix\matrix\src\components\homes\home\hero-slider.jsx)
</blog>
